questions.neutral: You look like you dodged something - true?

hobby.message: Origami's still better than meds, huh?
I hear analog photography still survives in your hands.

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: You could say that. City’s a mess tonight. Just needed a break.
I usually fold origami to unwind. Patterns help me focus.
It’s been hard with all the shouting outside lately.
Can’t seem to get a single fold right these days.
I guess dodging is the word. Neighborhood’s too loud for hobbies lately.
I fold paper—origami, when things are quiet. Helps organize my head.
Been on edge with those protests and all.
Tried folding a crane last night and tore it up halfway.
Seems like everything’s unsettled, even the small routines.
Yeah, barely slipped past the crowds and checkpoints. Couldn’t relax at home.
Used to do intricate origami models. Modular ones, with old forms.
The unrest outside wrecks my focus—hands kept trembling through every fold.
I tried to build a stellated ball last night. Gave up.
Background noise just seeps in lately. Makes patience impossible.
Whole city’s a jumble—guess my hobby’s caught up in it, too.
Feels like I dodged something every day—especially after those secret room revelations.
Origami is my favorite thing when I want quiet. Complex models, recycled scraps.
So much shouting in my block after the leak, I couldn’t fold straight.
Tried making a hydrangea tessellation—my hands wouldn’t steady.
I keep faulty models, by the way. Can’t throw them out lately.
Neighbors linger near stairwells, everyone watching doors.
I actually folded at work today, just to stay calm.
Definitely dodged more than trouble—with the city coming apart, hobbies feel different now.
I’ve folded origami for years—twenty, nearly. Keeps anxiety in check. Never talk about it.
Last week, protests echoed right up to my window. Made a cube, it collapsed.
I use payroll slips, council memos—anything scrap. Folding’s meditative. Sometimes it’s all I’ve got.
Used to be the rhythm grounded me. Now I spot mistakes in every crease.
Funny, after the big system blackout, I made a modular star by candlelight.
Felt both pointless and necessary. Like the world’s out of alignment.
Almost left the models behind if I had to run—couldn’t quite do it.
hobby_answer: Yeah, origami still helps. Sometimes.
Hard, lately. Streets are loud. Disruptive.
Not the same, with everything going on.
Crowds below my window—ruined a few pieces.
Feels harder to focus now.
Origami’s still my go-to when I need a break.
But last week, protests kept me awake all night.
Neighbors gathered outside; too much noise for fine folds.
Even my most basic cranes came out awkward.
Feels like the city’s energy seeps into the paper.
Can’t tune things out anymore.
Yeah, I’m still folding—mostly modular stuff, if I can.
Helps settle my thoughts when things get stressful.
After the protests started, though, everything’s been...tense. Hard to focus.
Tried a kusudama during the outage—couldn’t finish. Too jittery, I suppose.
City feels unpredictable now; even origami feels off-balance.
Ruined half my models the other night. Never used to happen.
Noise in the block seems to echo into my fingers.
Origami’s steadier than most things, but the past week’s shaken that.
Noise from the protests after Rada’s reveal—kept losing my rhythm.
Energy in the city feels like static in my head these days.
Paper crimps easier when my hands tremble. Never bothered me before.
Sometimes I hear alarms or shouting and fold shapes tighter, without thinking.
My building’s cameras glitched after the blackout, so I folded by candlelight.
Even simple models, like lotus flowers, turned out restless.
Feels like the system’s anxiety presses right through my hands into the paper.
Always been good with paper—keeps the mind from circling too tightly.
Used to fold in the break room, back when rules were clear.
Now, with all this Directorate mess and Rada’s exposé, it’s harder to settle in.
Tried to make a modular star just after the blackout ended—botched every connection.
Couldn’t stop thinking about who might be watching me fold, even alone.
I catch myself folding models that look tense, corners too sharp—like the city’s feeding back through me.
Even in my own flat, with the street full of chants, I flinch at every sound.
Sometimes I wish the paper could explain what it absorbs, all this background paranoia.
This isn’t what I pictured when I started, but stopping isn’t an option, either.
